description: On May 8th, The Health Ministry of Brunei urged the public not to discriminate against coronavirus-infected people.

On May 8th, The Brunei Health Ministry advised the public not to be fooled and believe in information and news being disseminated over the Internet or through other media such as  Whatsapp, Twitter, and  Facebook without ascertaining its authenticity.

On May 8th, the Brunei Health Ministry informed that whether orally or in writing or by any other means, disseminates false reports, or makes false statements, resulting in disruptive public order is punishable by up to three-year imprisonment and fined up to BND3,000.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
Brunei will restart in-school learning on June 2 for students who are sitting for public exams. Students in Year 6, 8, 10 Express, 11, 12 and 13 will be the first group to return to schools in the first phase of reopening, while other pupils will continue with online lessons. Teachers will conduct face-to-face learning from June 2-13 in the first phase of school reopening, after which the education ministry will decide whether to expand the number of returning students in the next phase.

All students are still expected to continue e-learning despite starting in-school classes, with schools determining the number of virtual learning days.
 UPDATE: Year 7, 9, 10 and sixth form centre students will be the next group to return to public and private schools in the education ministry’s third phase of reopening. All students are still expected to continue e-learning despite starting in-school classes, with schools determining the number of virtual learning days.

institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions

description: On April 30th, Brunei began using tracking bracelets named iMSafe for those ordered to undergo quarantine. The bracelets alert authorities when the device is taken off or if wearers break their COVID-19 quarantine, enabling authorities to remotely monitor and locate people who are placed under quarantine in real-time.
On May 1st Brunei is requiring all recovered patients to take the swab test again 11 days after they have been discharged.

The Ministry of Health  in  relation  to the  COVID-19  survey  conducted beginning on 4 May 2020 and ending on 6 May 2020, which aims to provide an overview of the estimated rates of infection among the community in  the  country,

Starting June 8th, patients and visitors have been urged to scan the BruHealth QR code at all hospitals and health centres. Patients and visitors will also be required to scan the QR code every time they enter or leave a specific department, such as pharmacy, clinic or a ward. BruHealth users with red codes will only be allowed to enter if they are patients who wish to see a doctor for consultation or to receive treatment at hospitals or health centres. For visitors, only those who have green and yellow codes can visit patients at hospital wards.

From Monday, 7 September 2020, premise owners in Brunei are required to print and display their QR code at their respective entrances. The public are urged to take the usage of the BruHealth application seriously, especially in scanning the QR Code as it is used by the Ministry of Health for contact tracing purposes in the event of an outbreak of infection.

description:
Brunei citizens and permanent residents who have received government approval to travel will pay a subsidised rate of $100 if they wish to take the swab test for coronavirus before leaving the country. Non-citizens, including green IC-holders, will be imposed $200 for the COVID-19 test. Tests are also free for those with special permission from the health ministry and government officers who are on official visits. Bruneian students who are pursuing their education abroad are exempted from paying for the nasal swab tests.

 UPDATE: reduction of the charges for the RT-PCR COVID-19 swab test imposed on foreigners that has been granted permission to enter the country from $1,000 (one thousand dollars) to $350 (three hundred and fifty dollars),
commencing Friday, 14 August 2020.
type_sub_cat: Test Kits
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: In Brunei, the health ministry has  started taking random tests on prisoners and residents at Al-Islah Rehabilitation Centre since April 16

The Brunei Ministry of Health hereby informs the public that starting 16 April 2020, all foreign travellers arriving to Brunei Darussalam are also required to bear the cost of the COVID-19 laboratory testing of B$1,000.00 per individual.

As of 29 April 2020, a total of 4,310 random COVID-‐19 tests for surveillance purposes were conducted among foreign workers and those present for treatment at Health Centers whose results were all negative.

The  Ministry of  Health extends the surveillance on the outbreak of  COVID-­‐19 infection among the citizens and residents of Brunei  Darussalam, the Ministry of Health will launch a nationwide survey   starting Monday,  4 May 2020 which will be conducted for a week. The  study involves taking in blood  samples and blood sugar test at home.
Brunei Ministry of Health will begin community antibody testing at select government health centers starting on May 3rd and children will not be tested as part of the nationwide survey.

The Health Ministry announced that Brunei started the one-week antibody testing at designated public health centers on Monday (11 May 2020) to have a better understanding of whether there is widespread community transmission of COVID-19.
Brunei's health ministry will also expand its COVID-19 testing among frontline healthcare workers and employees at childcare centres, pre-schools and elderly care centres from June 5.
The health ministry will conduct another round of COVID-19 antibody testing at select mosques this week to better understand the extent of community transmission in Brunei from June 15.
type_sub_cat: Health testing of entire population under the government's jurisdiction

description: On 14 August 2020, Brunei citizens and permanent residents who have received government approval to travel will pay a subsidised rate of $100 if they wish to take the swab test for coronavirus before leaving the country. Non-citizens, including green IC-holders, will be imposed $200 for the COVID-19 test. Tests are also free for those with special permission from the health ministry and government officers who are on official visits. Bruneian students who are pursuing their education abroad are exempted from paying for the nasal swab tests.
type_sub_cat: Health testing of entire population under the government's jurisdiction
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: Starting July 31st, The Brunei Ministry of Health would like to remind the public, especially for individuals who are seeking approval to travel abroad and to any countries that require for them to conduct a swab test for SARS-CoV-2 before arriving to the country, that at present the swab test can only be conducted at Government facilities or at facilities that are approved by the Government. Individuals who need to do a swab test for certain reasons are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha Hospital or at specific health centres that provide such services.

Starting July 31st, any premises in Brunei that offers swab test services without permission or recognition from the Ministry of Health is deemed to be in violation of the law which may result in a compound fine of up to $5000 or if convicted in court, can be fined up to $10,000 or imprisonment for up to 6 months or both.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: On Sept 9th, The Ministry of Health in Brunei would like to inform the public that individuals who would like to take the SARS-CoV-2 swab test, especially for the purpose of travelling abroad must take the swab test 3 – 5 days (three to five days) before their flight date – subject to the terms and conditions of the country to which it is intended. The results of the swab test will take time and the Ministry seeks the public’s patience while waiting for their test results.

As part of safety guidelines in Brunei, cleaning and disinfection of seats must be done every time a movie ends while cinemagoers should be kept at least two seats apart. Staff are also required to wear protective face masks, provide hand sanitisers and conduct temperature checks on cinema visitors from July 6.
type_sub_cat: Hygiene measures for public areas

description: A committee has been set up to discuss the possibility of establishing “green lanes” for international travel once Brunei starts lifting its border controls on 11 June.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
The government has yet to decide on resetting the 28-day countdown of easing coronavirus curbs despite reporting the first new case in 17 days
 UPDATE: The original relaxing health measures were set to last in 28 days but after the end of the 17th-day health minister decided to resetting 28-days
type_text: Brunei may relax public health measures when the country records zero new cases for 28 days in a row.

description: On May 7th, the Brunei government announces building tax cut for landlords; landlords who reduce their monthly rent of at least 10 percent will have their building tax lowered by 20 percent. Those who decreased their rent by 20 percent and above can enjoy a 50 percent tax cut.
type_text: Gov’t announces building tax cut for landlords
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Brunei government allowed one-to-one tuition and music classes from June 5 as part of further easing of restrictions in the government’s first phase of de-escalation. Tuition and music schools are required to obtain their QR code for the BruHealth mobile app and conduct temperature checks at their premises.
type_text: One-to-one tuition and music classes will be allowed from June 5 with QR quotes and temperature checks.

description: The Brunei government will use a new benchmark to determine the eligibility criteria of specific welfare recipients on July 15, and the Minimum Cost of Basic Goods (KMKA) approach and OECD-modified scale will be adopted to assess whether each applicant qualifies for the Department of Community Development’s welfare benefits
type_text: The government will use a new benchmark to determine the eligibility criteria of specific welfare recipients once the new digitalised welfare system starts operating on July 15

description: The Ministry of Health has a website with information on coronavirus, including FAQs, daily press releases, self-isolation policy, infographics and printable materials, videos, myth buster, disinfection and other guidelines, and a hotline call number (7 am-11 pm). Campaign website: http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/COVID-19.aspx since 6 January 2020.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Bruneian public is advised to maintain their hygiene to maximize protection against any microbial infections

Brunei Ministry of Health has developed its website to give daily updates and recommendations, including an official statement every day on the state of the virus and government measures. Press statements became daily after the first confirmed case in the country was diagnosed on 9 March 2020. The statements include daily reminders to the public to practice good hygiene, remain calm, and information regarding any resources they may need.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Starting 18 March 2020, the Ministry of Health with the collaboration from the Prime Minister’s Office and the E-Government National Centre (EGNC) and the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications will officially launch the use of the messaging application, Telegram to disseminate information and advice regarding COVID-19.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On March 24th, Brunei Gov’t launches app for users to monitor COVID-19 developments.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: #VaccinesWork on 27 April 2020 to raise awareness of the role of immunisation as one of the ways to protect people of all ages against vaccine-preventable diseases such as influenza, measles, mumps, rubella and so on. In this regard, despite Brunei Darussalam is currently experiencing the outbreak of COVID-19, the Ministry of Health continues to provide immunisation services at health centers across the country and in particular vaccination to children and the elderly. Parents and guardians are advised to make sure their children get the latest vaccination as scheduled.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On 6 May 2020, the Ministry of Health in Brunei would like to remind and emphasize the need for the public to continue to practice personal hygiene such as regular hand washing and proper coughing and sneezing etiquette.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On 7 August, the Ministry of Health in Brunei would like to emphasize the importance for the public to remain vigilant and take precautions by adopting and practice the preventive measures as recommended. This includes to practice physical distancing, avoid going to crowded places, wearing a face mask when unable to avoid going to crowded places, as well as maintaining personal hygiene such as frequently washing hands and maintaining personal hygiene, practice proper cough and sneeze etiquette.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description:
The Ministry of Health in Brunei will continue to monitor the situation of the
outbreak at the national as well as regional and global level and carry out ongoing risk assessments to consider further mitigation measures. If the outbreak situation becomes alarming yet again, the Ministry of Health will not hesitate to tighten the social distancing measures that need to be taken to control the outbreak. The Ministry of Health will notify the public of any changes to this situation, if necessary from time to time.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description:
On 13 August 2020, the Ministry of Health in Brunei would like to emphasize and remind the public to continue to comply with all the directives issued by the Government, as well as to practice their social responsibilities by maintaining personal hygiene, practice proper cough and sneeze etiquette, recommended to wear a face mask in crowded public places and if feeling unwell, not to go to public places and attend
social gatherings.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On 7 August 2020, the Ministry of Health in Brunei would like to remind the restaurant owners to comply with all rules and directives issued, especially to wear a face mask and for beauty and health establishments to use face masks and aprons. Any individual found to be in violation of or disobey any order issued shall be an offense under the Infectious Diseases Act (Section 204) which carries a compound fine of up to $5,000 or can be prosecuted in court carrying a fine of up to $10,000 or imprisonment up to 6 months or both. The Ministry will not hesitate to take legal action against anyone who does not comply with the directives issued.

description:
Brunei government will reopen senior citizen centres, museums, exhibition galleries and libraries on June 15.

For museums, exhibition galleries and libraries, group activities are allowed but limited to 30 people depending on the size of the venue. Outdoor activities are still banned.

The public facilities, which have been closed for nearly three months, will be open for three days a week for five hours.

Museums, public exhibition galleries and libraries will open every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday while private exhibition gallery owners will decide their opening hours.

description:
In Brunei, mosques, suraus, and other religious halls will reopen for Friday prayers from May 29 with safeguards in place. Precautions include requiring visitors to use the contact tracing application and limiting entry to men above 15 years old. Individuals caught breaching regulations could face a BND 10,000 (USD 7,100) fine and six months' imprisonment.

Mosques, surau and religious halls will be able to conduct group activities from July 6 as part of the third phase of the de-escalation plan, Al-Quran and Muqaddam classes are still not permitted, and group activities at places of worship are allowed for one hour and as long as the number of people does not exceed 50 people. UPDATE: Mosques, surau and religious halls will be able to conduct group activities from July 6 as part of the third phase of the de-escalation plan, Al-Quran and Muqaddam classes are still not permitted, and group activities at places of worship are allowed for one hour and as long as the number of people does not exceed 50 people.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

description:
On August 28th, the public in Brunei, especially those attending Friday prayers, are reminded to that wearing a face mask are required when they are within the compounds of the mosques, as well as bringing their own prayer mat and to scan the QR Code when entering the mosque and surau. Anyone who fails to comply with this directive is an offense under the Infectious
Disease Act (Section 204) which they can be fined up to $5,000 or if convicted in court, can be fined up to $10,000 or jailed for up to 6 months or both.
